sen.j: 千光寺（せんこうじ）は、奈良県生駒郡平群町にある真言宗醍醐派の寺院。
sen.e: Senko-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple of Daigo school of the Shingon sect situated in Heguri-cho, Ikoma County, Nara Prefecture.
Senko-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Daigo school of the Shingon sect situated in Heguri-cho, Ikoma County, Nara Prefecture.
Senko-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Daigo school of the Shingon sect situated in Heguri-cho, Ikoma County, Nara Prefecture.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Narukawasan.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Narukawasan.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Narukawasan.
It is commonly known as Motosanjosenko-ji Temple.
It is commonly known as Motosanjosenko-ji Temple.
It is commonly known as Motosanjosenko-ji Temple.

sen.j: ユースホステルの運営も行っている。
sen.e: It is also run as a youth hostel.
It is also run as a youth hostel.
It is also run as a youth hostel.
Origin
Origin
Origin

sen.j: 役行者がこの地に千手観音菩薩を安置し修行したのに始まるという。
sen.e: It is said that the temple's history started when the Thousand Armed Kannon Bosatsu (or Deity of Mercy) was enshrined in the place by EN no Gyoja, who practiced asceticism there.
It is said that the temple's history started when the Thousand Armed Kannon Bosatsu (or Deity of Mercy) was enshrined in the same location by EN no Gyoja, who practiced asceticism there.
It is said that the temple's history started when the Thousand Armed Kannon Bosatsu (or Deity of Mercy) was enshrined in the same location by EN no Gyoja, who practiced asceticism there.

sen.j: 役行者霊跡第15番札所となっている。
sen.e: The temple is one of En no Gyoja's holy places and the 15th fudasho (temple where amulets are collected).
The temple is one of En no Gyoja's holy places and the 15th fudasho (temple where amulets are collected).
The temple is one of En no Gyoja's holy places and the 15th fudasho (temple where amulets are collected).
Fudasho (Temple Where Amulets Are Collected)
Fudasho
Fudasho

sen.j: 仏塔古寺十八尊 第14番
sen.e: The 14th temple of the 18 Butto Koji (Historical Temples with Pagodas)
It is the 14th temple of the eighteen Butto Koji (Historical Temples with Pagodas).
It is the 14th temple of the eighteen Butto Koji (Historical Temples with Pagodas).
En no Gyoja's holy place and fudasho
It is also one of En no Gyoja's holy places and a fudasho.
It is also one of En no Gyoja's holy places and a fudasho.
Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties

sen.j: 梵鐘（県指定有形文化財）
sen.e: Bonsho (The Buddhist temple bell, a tangible cultural property designated by the prefecture)
Bonsho (the Buddhist temple bell) is a Tangible Cultural Property designated by the prefecture.
Bonsho (the Buddhist temple bell) is a Tangible Cultural Property designated by the prefecture.

sen.j: 役行者・前鬼・後鬼像（町指定有形文化財）
sen.e: The statues of EN no Gyoja, Zenki and Goki (Oni demons in front and back serving En) (tangible cultural properties designated by the town)
The statues of EN no Gyoja, Zenki and Goki (Oni demons at the front and back of the temple, and who serve En) are Tangible Cultural Properties designated by the town.
The statues of EN no Gyoja, Zenki and Goki (Oni demons at the front and back of the temple, and who serve En) are Tangible Cultural Properties designated by the town.

sen.j: 磨崖石仏群（町指定有形文化財）
sen.e: The statues carved on a natural rock wall (tangible cultural properties designated by the town)
The statues carved out of a natural rock wall are Tangible Cultural Properties designated by the town.
The statues carved on a natural rock wall are Tangible Cultural Properties designated by the town.
sen.cmt: 磨崖仏は、崖に掘られた(on)仏であり、崖から切り出された(out of)石仏ではありません。
